anchor.surface_text: 1950. December 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAzL ALI J.--This is an appeal

facts.text: Reference concerns assessment of the appellant to income-tax for the year 1942-43

anchor.surface_text: by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in compannection with the assessment of the appellant to income-tax for the year 1942-43.

facts.text: Question of law: Whether the assessee, a Hindu undivided family, is resident in British India under section 4A(b) of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The question of law referred to the High Court was as fol- lows -- Whether in the circumstances of the case, the assessee  a Hindu undivided family  is resident

facts.text: Appellant is the karta of a joint Hindu family

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances of the case may be briefly stated as follows. The appellant is the karta of a joint Hindu family

facts.text: Appellant has been living in Ceylon with his wife, son and three daughters

anchor.surface_text: and has been living in Ceylon with his wife, son and three daughters, and they are stated to be domiciled

facts.text: Appellant and family domiciled in Ceylon

anchor.surface_text: with his wife, son and three daughters, and they are stated to be domiciled in that companyntry.

facts.text: Appellant carries on business in Colombo under the name and style of the General Trading Corporation

anchor.surface_text: He carries on business in Colombo under the name and style of the General Trading Corporation, and he owns a house,

facts.text: Appellant owns a house, some immovable property and investments in British India

anchor.surface_text: the General Trading Corporation, and he owns a house, some immoveable property and investments in British India.

facts.text: Appellant has shares in two firms situated at Vijayapuram and Nagapatnam in British India

anchor.surface_text: He has also shares in two firms situated at Vijayapuram and Nagapatnam in British India.

facts.text: In the year of account 1941-42, appellant visited British India on seven occasions, total period of stay 101 days

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account, 1941- 42, which is the basis of the present assessment, the appel- lant is said to have visited British India on seven occa- sions

facts.text: During stays in British India, appellant personally attended to litigation relating to family lands in trial court and court of appeal

anchor.surface_text: During such stays, he personally attended to a litiga- tion relating to the family lands both in the trial Court and in the Court of appeal.

facts.text: Appellant attended income-tax proceedings relating to assessment of family income, appearing before authorities at Karaikudi and Madras

anchor.surface_text: He was also attending the in- companye-tax proceedings relating to the assessment of the family income, appearing before the income-tax authorities

facts.text: On one occasion, appellant obtained extension of time for payment of tax after interviewing the authority concerned

anchor.surface_text: at Karaikudi and Madras. On one of these occasions, he obtained an extension of time for payment of the tax after interviewing

facts.text: Appellant did not produce file of correspondence with business in Colombo

anchor.surface_text: The other facts relied upon by the income-tax authori- ties were that he did number produce the file of companyrespondence

facts.text: Appellant started two partnership businesses in India on 25th February, 1942

anchor.surface_text: he had started two partnership businesses in India on 25th February, 1942, and remained in India for some time

facts.text: Appellant remained in India for some time after commencement of those businesses

anchor.surface_text: in India on 25th February, 1942, and remained in India for some time after the companymencement of those busi- nesses.

arguments.claim: On the one hand, the head and karta permanently lives in Colombo and family domiciled in Ceylon, but onus not discharged due to lack of evidence

anchor.surface_text: On the one hand, we have the fact that the head and karta of the asses- sees family who companytrols and manages its affairs permanent- ly lives in Colombo and the family is domiciled in Ceylon.

holdings.text: A Hindu undivided family is normally taken to be resident in the taxable territories unless the control and management of its affairs is situated wholly without British India

anchor.surface_text: Section 4A b runs thus-- For the purposes of this Act---- A Hindu undivided family, firm or other association of per- sons is resident in British India unless the control and management of its affairs is situated wholly without British India. It will be noticed that section 4A deals with residence in the taxable territories, of  a individuals,  b a Hindu undivided family, firm or other association of persons, and  c  a company. In each of these cases, certain tests have been laid down, and the test with which we are concerned is that laid down in section 4A b . This provi- sion appears to be based very largely on the rule which has been applied in England to cases of corporations

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction of s.4A(b) creates presumption of residency rebuttable only by proving exception of wholly external control and management

holdings.text: The word 'affairs' in s.4A(b) means affairs relevant for the purpose of the Income-tax Act and which have some relation to income

anchor.surface_text: The words used in this provision clearly show firstly, that, normally, a Hindu undivided family will be taken to be resident in the taxable territories, but such a presumption will not apply if the case can be brought under the second part c,f the provision. Secondly, we take it that the word affairs must mean affairs which are relevant for the purpose of the Income-tax Act and which have some-relation to income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation limiting 'affairs' to income-related matters for tax residency determination

holdings.text: Control and management refers to the seat of direction and control of the affairs of the family

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, we take it that the word affairs must mean affairs which are relevant for the purpose of the Income-tax Act and which have some-relation to income. Thirdly, in order to bring the case under the exception, we have to ask whether the seat of the direction and control of the affairs of the family is inside or out- side British India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts and applies English company law analogy where central management and control determines residence

holdings.text: The word 'wholly' recognizes possibility of divided seat of control allowing multiple residences for HUF similar to corporation

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, in order to bring the case under the exception, we have to ask whether the seat of the direction and control of the affairs of the family is inside or out- side British India. Lastly, the word wholly suggests that a Hindu undivided family may have more than One resi- dence in the same way as a corporation may have.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of 'wholly situated' permits division but requires proof for exception

holdings.text: Mere ownership of house in British India where mother lives does not constitute seat of control and management

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the mere fact that the assessee has a house at Kanadukathan, where his mother lives, cannot constitute that place the seat of control and management of the affairs of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of control test to specific facts; real control not inferred from property ownership alone

holdings.text: Stays in British India for litigation and income-tax proceedings do not shift seat of control and management

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we inclined in the cir- cumstances of the present case to attach much importance to the fact that the assessee had to stay in British India for 101 days in a particular year. He was undoubtedly interest- ed in the litigation with regard to his family property as well as in the income-tax proceedings, and by merely coming out to India to take part in them, he cannot be said to have shifted the seat of management and control of the affairs of his family, or to have started a second centre for such control and management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes occasional activities from central directive power

holdings.text: Starting partnership businesses and mere activity in British India is not the test of residence; central control governs

anchor.surface_text: The same remark must apply to the starting of two partnership businesses, as mere activity cannot be the test of residence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects activity-based test in favor of control and management location per precedents

holdings.text: Onus of proving control and management wholly outside British India lies on the assessee claiming the exception under s.4A(b)

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the onus of proving facts which would bring his case within the exception, which is provided by the latter part of section 4A b , was on the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exception to general residency rule places evidentiary burden on claimant

holdings.text: Assessee failed to discharge onus as did not produce correspondence or evidence showing control from Colombo despite being called upon to do so

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was called upon to adduce evidence to show that the control and management of the affairs of the family was situated wholly outside the taxable territo- ries, but the correspondence to which the Assistant Commis- sioner of Income-tax refers and other material evidence which might have shown that normally and as a matter of course the affairs in India were also being controlled from Colombo were not produced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of evidence despite opportunity leads to failure to rebut presumption

holdings.text: Control and management of assessee's affairs not situated wholly outside British India; assessee HUF is resident under s.4A(b)

anchor.surface_text: The question which now arises is what is the result of the application of these principles to this case, and whether it can be held that the central control and management of the affairs of the assessees family has been shown to be divid- ed in this case. ... The position therefore is this. On the one hand, we have the fact that the head and karta of the asses- sees family who controls and manages its affairs permanent- ly lives in Colombo and the family is domiciled in Ceylon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.4A(b) test to facts, presumption, onus failure, and balancing evidence leads to residency finding

anchor.surface_text: De Beers Howe 1 . A companypany cannot eat or sleep, but it can keep house and do business. We ought, therefore, to see where it really keeps house and does business The decision of Chief Baron Kelly and Baron Huddleston in The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson

precedents.cited_proposition: A company resides where it really keeps house and does business, i.e., where the central management and control actually abides
precedents.cited_holding: A company cannot eat or sleep, but it can keep house and do business. [...] where the central management and control actually abides

precedents.citation: The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson 2

anchor.surface_text: The decision of Chief Baron Kelly and Baron Huddleston in The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson and The Cessna Sulphur Company v. Nichol- son 2 , number thirty years ago, involved the principle that a companypany resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on.

precedents.case_name: The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson
precedents.cited_proposition: A company resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on

precedents.citation: The Cessna Sulphur Company v. Nicholson 2

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson and The Cessna Sulphur Company v. Nichol- son 2 , number thirty years ago, involved the principle that a companypany resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on. Those decisions have been acted upon ever since.

precedents.case_name: The Cessna Sulphur Company v. Nicholson
precedents.cited_proposition: A company resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on

precedents.citation: Swedish Central Railway Company Limited v. Thompson 1

anchor.surface_text: Swedish Central Railway Company Limited v. Thompson 1 , which is one of the leading cases on the subject, are --  1  that the exception of residence in the case of a fictitious person , such as a companypany, is as artificial as the companypany itself, and the locality of the residence can only be determined by analogy, by asking where is the head and seat and directing power of the affairs of the companypany.

precedents.case_name: Swedish Central Railway Company Limited v. Thompson
precedents.cited_proposition: The locality of residence of a company is determined by where is the head and seat and directing power of its affairs
precedents.cited_holding: the exception of residence in the case of a fictitious person, such as a company, is as artificial as the company itself, and the locality of the residence can only be determined by analogy, by asking where is the head and seat and directing power of the affairs of the company

anchor.surface_text: Section 4A b runs thus-- For the purposes of this Act---- A Hindu undivided family, firm or other association of per- sons is resident in British India unless the control and management of its affairs is situated wholly without British India. It will be noticed that section 4A deals with residence in the taxable territories, of  a individuals,  b a Hindu undivided family, firm or other association of persons, and  c  a company. In each of these cases, certain tests have been laid down, and the test with which we are concerned is that laid down in section 4A b . This provi- sion appears to be based very largely on the rule which has been applied in England to cases of corporations

The position therefore is this. On the one hand, we have the fact that the head and karta of the asses- sees family who controls and manages its affairs permanent- ly lives in Colombo and the family is domiciled in Ceylon.
